sen.j: 「勧修寺」の寺名とともに、今日では「かじゅうじ」と読むのが一般的だが、中世日本の書籍等では「くわんしゆし」との平仮名表記も散見され、「かんじゅじ」とも読まれていたことがうかがわれる。
sen.e: The family name is generally read as "Kajuji" these days together with the name of "Kaju-ji Temple", though, the description of "kuwanshiyushi" in Japanese syllabary characters found occasionally in the books in the medieval Japan suggests that it was also read as "Kanjuji".

Today, the characters of the family name are generally read, in the same way as those of the temple by the same name, as "Kajuji", but the hiragana (today read as "kuwanshiyushi") occasionally found in medieval books suggests that they were also read as "Kanjuji".

sen.j: 勧修寺流は、山科の勧修寺を一門の結束の精神的な拠所とし、傾向としては他の流派よりも比較的堅く、また家職として朝廷の実務を担当する家が多く、弁官や摂関家家司を多く輩出していることで知られる。
sen.e: The Kajuji/Kanjuji ryu set Kaju-ji Temple in Yamashina as the place of their spiritual unification of the family; they were tend to be more serious than the other lineages and a lot of families were responsible for practical works of the Imperial Court; they were well-known for the fact that they produced many benkan (Oversight department) and the Sekkanke keishi (a section handling domestic affairs of lines of regents and advisers).

sen.j: 後世の実務の参考となるよう、先例を書き留めておく必要があることから、詳細な日記を残すことも求められ、勧修寺流は「日記の家」と称されるようになり、各家当主による日記も豊富に残されている。
sen.e: As they were required to leave detailed diaries which recorded historical precedence for the future practical reference, the Kaju-ji/Kanjuji ryu were called "the family of diary", and a lot of diaries by the heads of each family were left.

sen.j: 為輔の玄孫・藤原為房は白河天皇の院近臣、関白藤原師実・藤原師通の家司となり、勧修寺流中興の祖とされる。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Tamefusa, a great-great-grandson of Tamesuke, became a personal attendant of Emperor Shirakawa and a keishi of FUJIWARA no Morozane and FUJIWARA no Moromichi, who were both kampaku (a post held by a person that governs in the Emperor's stead), and is supposed to be the ancestor of the restoration of the Kajuji/Kanjuji ryu.
